guide.title: dynfw Dynamic Firewall Tools, v1.0
guide.abstract: Firewalls all good and fun, but what do you do when you need to make rapid, complex changes to your iptables-based firewall rules? Easy -- use the dynfw Dynamic Firewall Tools, a collection of robust bash scripts that are designed to work with nearly any existing iptables-based firewall configuration. You can use these scripts to increase your network security and responsiveness, and as inspiration for your own creative designs.

body.p:
The dynfw scripts originated from an article I wrote for IBM developerWorks that showed how to make a firewall more responsive by creating scripts that automate common "firewall-tweaking" tasks, such as blocking an IP, ratelimiting a host, etc. The reason for the scripts is simple -- when you're in a crisis, you don't want to make changes to your master firewall script in a frantic state. Instead, you want to have an already-existing and easy-to-use mechanism to make those changes for you, eliminating the possibility of error and allowing immediate response.
You can read the original IBM developerWorks dynfw article, which explains how to use the scripts.
You can download the current version of dynfw here: dynfw-1.0.tar.gz.
The dynfw Dynamic Firewall Tools are Copyright 2001 Gentoo Technologies, Inc. and distributed under the GNU Public License.You are encouraged to send any bug fixes or improvements to these tools to Daniel Robbins so that they can be rolled into the official release.
The following scripts are included in dynfw-1.0.tar.gz:
ScriptDescription
install.shthe install script -- run this first
dynfw.shthe dynfw global support script -- used by all dynfw tools
ipdropdiscard packets coming from a specific IP
ipblockdiscard as above, but send an TCP reset if applicable
tcplimitratelimit new connections to a local TCP port
host-tcplimitratelimit new connections from a specific host
user-outblockprevents a specific UID (user) from establishing outbound connections
